DT Article
TI Checklist for Planktonic Ciliates (Protozoa, Ciliophora) living in
   Velacherry Lake, Chennai, India.
AU Rajabunizal, K. (rramani8@hotmail.com) 
   Ramanibai, R.
SO Bugs 'R' All
VL 20
PS 22-25
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The checklist of the planktonic ciliate assemblage in Velacherry Lake,
   Chennai, India was investigated from January 2010 to December 2010. A
   total number of 46 species of protozoan ciliates come under 28 genera,
   26 families and 10 orders were recorded. The order Peritrichida with 5
   families was recorded with maximum number of 21 species. The minimum
   number of species (1 sp.) was recorded in the orders like
   Pleurostomatida, Nassulida and Cyrtophorida. The aim of this study is to
   give a report on protozoan ciliates in a freshwater body Velacherry
   lake. All the 46 species are reported for the first time from the state
   of Tamil Nadu in India.
C1 Rajabunizal, K.; Univ Madras, Dept Zool, Guindy Campus, Madras, Tamil
   Nadu, 600025, India, India.
EM rramani8@hotmail.com

   Velacherry Lake / ].

AN ZOOR15106033725
DT Article
TI EFFICACY OF HERBAL ECTOPARASITICIDES IN CAPTIVE RAT SNAKES (PTYAS
   MUCOSUS) REARED IN INDIA.
AU Rajesh, N.V. (crocvet@gmail.com) 
   Jayathangaraj, M.G.
   Sridhar, R.
   Raman, M.
SO Bulgarian Journal of Veterinary Medicine
VL 16
IS 3
PS 223-227
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The efficacy of herbal extracts from the plants Vitex negundo and Acorus
   calamus against tick infestation in rat snakes (Ptyas mucosus)
   maintained under captivity was studied and compared to that of
   Ivermectin. A total of 6 rat snakes affected with heavy tick infestation
   were taken for the study. Investigation of ectoparasites in snakes under
   captivity showed abundance of Aponomma sp. ticks. The anti-parasitic
   treatments were conducted with ivermectin at the dose rate of 200
   [mu]g/kg body weight, applied subcutaneously (n=2) and with herbal
   preparation from Vitex negundo (n=2) and Acorus calamus (n=2) at the
   dose of 0.05% aqueous solution applied on the body. Number of ticks was
   counted on day 0, day 3, day 5 and day 7, respectively for comparison of
   drug efficacy in a 10x5 cm2 area in four quadrants of the snake body
   (the fore quarter, the right and left abdomen and the tail part). It was
   concluded that in tick-infested rat snakes, herbal preparations from
   Vitex negundo (56.7%) and Acorus calamus (68.3%) showed no side effects
   but their efficacy did not reach that of Ivermectin (94.5%).
C1 Rajesh, N.V.; Madras Vet Coll, Dept Wildlife Sci, Chennai, Tamil Nadu,
   600007, India, India.
EM crocvet@gmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Aponomma [Reptilian hosts / Ptyas mucosus / Infestation] [Tamil Nadu /
   Chennai, Agrignar Anna Zoological Park / ]. 
   Ptyas mucosus [Arachnid parasites / Aponomma / Infestation; captivity;
   effect of herbal plant extract] [Tamil Nadu / Chennai, Agrignar Anna
   Zoological Park / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Chordates; Invertebrates; Reptiles;
   Vertebrates

   Lepidosauria, Squamata, Serpentes, Colubridae

   Ptyas mucosus (Colubridae): [Host].

PT J
AN ZOOR15402009014
DT Article
TI Allogenarchopsis gen. nov. (Digenea, Derogenidae, Halipeginae) Parasitic
   in the Intestine of Freshwater Fishes: a Molecular and Morphological
   Study of Adult and Cercarial Forms.
AU Urabe, Misako (urabe@ses.usp.ac.jp) 
   Shimazu, Takeshi
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
VL 39
IS 3
PS 119-130
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Adults of Genarchopsis yaritanago Shimazu et al., 2011 (Digenea,
   Derogenidae, Halipeginae) were found in the intestine of Tanakia
   lanceolata (Temminck and Schlegel, 1846) (type host), Tanakia limbata
   (Temminck and Schlegel, 1846) (new host record), Rhodeus ocellatus
   ocellatus (Kner, 1866) (new host record) and Acheilognathus rhombeus
   (Temminck and Schlegel, 1846) (new host record) (Cyprinidae,
   Acheilognathinae) from the Lake Biwa basin in Shiga Prefecture, central
   Japan. Daughter rediae and cercariae of Cercaria problematica Faust,
   1924 were found in Semisulcospira reiniana (Brot, 1874) (Gastropoda,
   Sorbeoconcha, Pleuroceridae) from the same basin. The cytochrome c
   oxidase subunit I gene (COI) of the mitochondrial DNA of the adult and
   cercaria was partially sequenced. Morphological and molecular studies
   showed that G. yaritanago and C. problematica are the same species, that
   the original description by Shimazu et al. (2011) includes some errors
   of taxonomic importance at the generic level, and that G. yaritanago
   should be removed to another genus. Allogenarchopsis gen. nov.
   (Halipeginae) is proposed. The type species is Allogenarchopsis
   yaritanago (Shimazu et al., 2011) comb. nov. The species name of the
   taxon is changed from A. yaritanago to Allogenarchopsis problematica
   (Faust, 1924) comb. nov. (syn. C. problematica, Cercaria manei Ito,
   1960, G. yaritanago, A. yaritanago). The adult, daughter redia and
   cercaria are described and figured.
C1 Urabe, Misako; Univ Shiga Prefecture, Sch Environm Sci, 2500 Hassaka,
   Hikone, Shiga, 5228533, Japan, Japan.
EM urabe@ses.usp.ac.jp
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1881-9052
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Parasites diseases
   and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Acheilognathus rhombeus; Rhodeus ocellatus ocellatus; Tanakia limbata
   [Digenean parasites / Allogenarchopsis problematica / New record;
   parasite systematics] [Japan / Honshu, Shiga, Lake Biwa / ]. 
   Allogenarchopsis problematica [Piscean hosts / Acheilognathus rhombeus /
   New record; systematics] [ / Rhodeus ocellatus ocellatus / ] [ / Tanakia
   limbata / ] [Japan / Honshu, Shiga, Lake Biwa / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae, Platyhelminthes, Trematoda, Digenea
OR Acheilognathus rhombeus (Cyprinidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Rhodeus ocellatus ocellatus (Cyprinidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Tanakia limbata (Cyprinidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Allogenarchopsis (Digenea): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Halipeginae, Type
   species Genarchopsis yaritanago Shimazu et al 2011, p. 122]. 
   Allogenarchopsis problematica - (Faust 1924) (Digenea): [Redescription,
   P. 122; Comb nov, Transferred from Cercaria, p. 122; Senior synonym, Of
   Cercaria manei Ito 1960, p. 126; Senior synonym, Of Genarchopsis
   yaritanago Shimazu, Urabe & Grygier 2011, p. 126; Parasite; New record].
   
   Cercaria manei - Ito 1960 (Digenea): [Junior synonym, Of
   Allogenarchopsis problematica (Faust 1924), p. 126].

   Allogenarchopsis, p. 122].

PT J
AN ZOOR15402009016
DT Article
TI Cabillus pexus, a New Marine Goby (Teleostei, Gobiidae) from
   Amami-oshima Island, Ryukyu Islands, Japan.
AU Shibukawa, Koichi (kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp) 
   Aizawa, Masahiro
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
VL 39
IS 3
PS 133-142
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of gobiine goby, Cabillus pexus, is described based on two
   specimens (15.5 mm and 22.4 mm in standard lengths) from Amami-oshima
   Island, Amami Group of the Ryukyu Islands, Japan. The species is readily
   distinguished from congeners (except for Cabillus caudimacula from the
   Hawaiian Islands) by having a pair of modified scales with enlarged
   ctenii at the base of the caudal fin. Cabillus pexus differs from C.
   caudimacula in having: five predorsal scales in adults (vs. predorsal
   scales absent in C. caudimacula); prepelvic area with cycloid scales
   (vs. naked); ctenoid scale area on side of body extending anteriorly to
   a vertical through base of third ray of second dorsal fin (vs. extending
   to a vertical through midbase of first dorsal fin); a narrow black
   transverse bar at base of caudal fin (vs. a distinctive, large dark
   blotch posteriorly on side of caudal peduncle and extending onto base of
   caudal fin); a prominent black submarginal spot at fin membrane between
   first and third spines of first dorsal fin (vs. prominent black spots
   absent); 1-2 + 4-5 gill rakers (vs. 1-2 + 2-3).
C1 Shibukawa, Koichi; Nagao Nat Environm Fdn, Sumida Ku, 3-3-7 Kotobashi,
   Tokyo, 1300022, Japan, Japan.
EM kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1881-9052
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Cabillus pexus [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Gobiidae
OR Cabillus atripelvicus species complex (Gobiidae): [New species group, P.
   140]. 
   Cabillus pexus (Gobiidae): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 135].

PT J
AN ZOOR15402009017
DT Article
TI Gobiodon aoyagii, a New Coral Goby (Actinopterygii, Gobiidae, Gobiinae)
   from the West Pacific, with Redescription of a Similarly-colored
   Congener Gobiodon erythrospilus Bleeker, 1875.
AU Shibukawa, Koichi (kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp) 
   Suzuki, Toshiyuki
   Aizawa, Masahiro
SO Bulletin of the National Museum of Nature and Science Series A Zoology
VL 39
IS 3
PS 143-165
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of coral goby, Gobiodon aoyagii, is described based on 57
   specimens collected from the West Pacific. Gobiodon aoyagii is unique
   within the genus by having 3-4 rows of weakly ctenoid and/or cycloid
   scales on caudal peduncle. Furthermore, G. aoyagii differs from the
   congeners by the following combination of characters: a deep, inflected
   interopercular-isthmus groove; 5-6 upper or lower unsegmented caudal-fin
   rays; no distinct dusky spot at dorsoposterior corner of operculum; when
   alive or freshly-collected, 2 reddish circular spots on the pectoral-fin
   base; no reddish crescent-like bar along bases of pectoral-fin rays;
   reddish spots on the ventral surface of head. Our examination of 45 (of
   86) syntypes of a similarly-colored congener G. erythrospilus reveals
   that these syntypes comprise 4 distinct species, viz., G. erythrospilus,
   G. histrio, G. aoyagii and an unidentifiable species. Gobiodon
   erythrospilus is re-described based on 25 syntypes and additional 49
   specimens from Japan and Micronesia, and a lectotype is designated.
C1 Shibukawa, Koichi; Nagao Nat Environm Fdn, Taito Ku, 3-10-10 Shitaya,
   Tokyo, 1100004, Japan, Japan.
EM kshibukawa@nagaofoundation.or.jp
SC Zoology
SN 1881-9052
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Diagnosis;
   Description; Synonymy; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Gobiodon aoyagii [North Pacific / Japan / New species] [ / Philippines /
   ] [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Gobiidae
OR Gobiodon aoyagii (Gobiidae): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 147]. 
   Gobiodon erythrispilus - Bleeker 1875 (Gobiidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 162; Emended diagnosis, P. 154; Senior synonym, Of Gobius
   douglasi Saville-Kent 1893, p. 162]. 
   Gobiodon erythrospilus - Bleeker 1875 (Gobiidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 155; Redescription, P. 155]. 
   Gobiodon histrio - (Valenciennes 1837) (Gobiidae): [Senior synonym, Of
   Gobiodon verticalis Alleyne & Macleay 1877, p. 162]. 
   Gobiodon verticalis - Alleyne & Macleay 1877 (Gobiidae): [Junior
   synonym, Of Gobiodon histrio (Valenciennes 1837), p. 162]. 
   Gobius douglasi - Saville-Kent 1893 (Gobiidae): [Junior synonym, Of
   Gobiodon erythrispilus Bleeker 1875, p. 162].

PT J
AN ZOOR15010057161
DT Article
TI ABOUT SPECIES OF THE GENUS ANITYS THOMSON, 1863 (COLEOPTERA: PTINIDAE:
   DORCATOMINAE).
AU Toskina, I.N.
SO Byulleten' Moskovskogo Obshchestva Ispytatelei Prirody Otdel
   Biologicheskii
VL 118
IS 5
PS 40-44
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB After studying the aedeagi and other morphological details in species of
   the genus Anitys Thomson, 1863 there was found the heterogeneity of
   species of A. rubens (Hoffmann, 1803) in the collection of the
   Zoological Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences and new species
   A. lineata sp. nov. was separated out. These beetles are
   grayish-brownish-yellow, hemispherical; 6th and 7th antennal segments
   (club) look as broad teeth with convex lower margins, 8th segment is
   broad; elytra are provided with striae on disc; the middle of
   metasternum is strongly convex and with rather broad longitudinal median
   groove; metafemoral plaques have a prominent angle in the middle, rather
   broad in the proximal half; abdominal sutures are strongly reduced
   between 2nd and 3rd sternites and between 3rd and 4th ones. Aedeagus
   differs in many details from the aedeagus of A. rubens given by Espanol,
   1977, fig. 101 (or Fig. 1, I in this article). We proved that A. cognata
   (Mulsant and Rey, 1864) is a bona sp. because its aedeagus and other
   morphological details have characters different from A. rubens.
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Entomology
SN 0027-1403
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; General morphology;
   Reproduction; Reproductive system; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Anitys [General morphology /  / systematics] [Aedeagus /  / ]. 
   Anitys lineata [Austria /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Bostrichoidea,
   Anobiidae
OR Anitys (Anobiidae). 
   Anitys cognata - (Mulsant & Rey 1864) (Anobiidae): [Status, P. 40]. 
   Anitys lineata (Anobiidae): [Sp nov, Austria, type horizon not given, P.
   44].

DT Article
TI Three new Mitridae (Gastropoda) species from French Polynesia with a new
   record for Mitra cernohorskyi (REHDER & WILSON, 1975).
AU Herrmann, Manfred (mitridae@gmx.de) 
   Salisbury, Richard A.
SO Conchylia
VL 44
IS 1-2
PS 31-43
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Between 1997 and 2009 three expeditions to different parts of French
   Polynesia were organized by MNHN and IRD. Three new deep water species
   of the genera Mitra and Cancilla from these cruises are described
   herein: Mitra structilis n. sp. from the Austral Islands, compared with
   Mitra rinaldii TURNER, 1993 from Somalia and with Mitra geigeri (POPPE,
   TAGARO & SALISBURY, 2009) from the Philippines; Mitra (Nebularia) tabida
   n. sp. from the Tuamotus and the Marquesas, compared with M. (N.)
   tuberosa REEVE, 1845 and with M. (N.) lugubris SWAINSON, 1821. A third
   species, Cancilla fluctuosa n. sp. from the Marquesas and Austral
   Islands, is compared with Cancilla apprimapex POPPE, TAGARO & SALISBURY,
   2009 and with Neocancilla armonica (T. COSSIGNANI & V. COSSIGNANI, 2005)
   from the Indo-Pacific. In addition, the range for Mitra cernohorskyi
   (REHDER & WILSON, 1975) is extended northwards to the Austral Islands.
C1 Herrmann, Manfred; Ulmenstr 14, Rosdorf, D-37124, Germany, Germany.
EM mitridae@gmx.de

   Mitra structilis [South Pacific / Tubuai Islands / New species].

   species from this department is provided.

PT J
AN ZOOR15004017546
DT Article
TI A new species of lowland tailorbird (Passeriformes: Cisticolidae:
   Orthotomus) from the Mekong floodplain of Cambodia.
AU Mahood, S.P. (smahood@wcs.org) 
   John, A.J.I.
   Eames, J.C.
   Oliveros, C.H.
   Moyle, R.G.
   Chamnan, Hong
   Poole, C.M.
   Nielsen, H.
   Sheldon, F.H.
SO Forktail
VL 29
PS 1-14
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Based on distinctive morphological and vocal characters we describe a
   new species of lowland tailorbird Orthotomus from dense humid lowland
   scrub in the floodplain of the Mekong, Tonle Sap and Bassac rivers of
   Cambodia. Genetic data place it in the O. atrogularis-O. ruficeps-O.
   sepium clade. All data suggest that the new species is most closely
   related to O. atrogularis, from which genetic differences are apparently
   of a level usually associated with subspecies. However the two taxa
   behave as biological species, existing locally in sympatry and even
   exceptionally in syntopy, without apparent hybridisation. The species is
   known so far from a small area within which its habitat is declining in
   area and quality. However, although birds are found in a number of small
   habitat fragments (including within the city limits of Phnom Penh), most
   individuals probably occupy one large contiguous area of habitat in the
   Tonle Sap floodplain. We therefore recommend it is classified as Near
   Threatened on the IUCN Red List. The new species is abundant in suitable
   habitat within its small range. Further work is required to understand
   more clearly the distribution and ecology of this species and in
   particular its evolutionary relationship with O. atrogularis.
C1 Mahood, S.P.; Wildlife Conservat Soc Cambodia Program, POB 1620, Phnom
   Penh, Cambodia, Cambodia.
EM smahood@wcs.org
OI Oliveros, Carl/0000-0002-3356-246X
SC Zoology
SN 0950-1746
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Orthotomus chaktomuk [Cambodia /  / New species]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Passeriformes, Sylviidae
OR Orthotomus (Sylviidae): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate taxa,
   Adult male plumage, p. 3]. 
   Orthotomus chaktomuk (Sylviidae): [Sp nov, Cambodia, P. 2].

AN ZOOR15001003633
PM 24068425
DT Article
TI XX/XO, a rare sex chromosome system in Potamotrygon freshwater stingray
   from the Amazon Basin, Brazil.
AU de Souza Valentim, Francisco Carlos (valentim@inpa.gov.br) 
   Rebelo Porto, Jorge Ivan
   Carlos Bertollo, Luiz Antonio
   Gross, Maria Claudia
   Feldberg, Eliana
SO Genetica (Dordrecht)
VL 141
IS 7-9
PS 381-387
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Potamotrygonidae is a representative family of South American freshwater
   elasmobranchs. Cytogenetic studies were performed in a Potamotrygon
   species from the middle Negro River, Amazonas, Brazil, here named as
   Potamotrygon sp. C. Mitotic and meiotic chromosomes were analyzed using
   conventional staining techniques, C-banding, and detection of the
   nucleolus organizing regions (NOR) with Silver nitrate (Ag-NOR). The
   diploid number was distinct between sexes, with males having 2n = 67
   chromosomes, karyotype formula 19m + 8sm + 10st + 30a, and fundamental
   number (FN) = 104, and females having 2n = 68 chromosomes, karyotype
   formula 20m + 8sm + 10st + 30a, and FN = 106. A large chromosome,
   corresponding to pair number two in the female karyotype, was missing in
   the male complement. Male meiotic cells had 33 bivalents plus a large
   univalent chromosome in metaphase I, and n = 33 and n = 34 chromosomes
   in metaphase II. These characteristics are consistent with a sex
   chromosome system of the XX/XO type. Several Ag-NOR sites were
   identified in both male and female karyotypes. Positive C-banding was
   located only in the centromeric regions of the chromosomes. This sex
   chromosome system, which rarely occurs in fish, is now being described
   for the first time among the freshwater rays of the Amazon basin.
C1 de Souza Valentim, Francisco Carlos; Inst Nacl Pesquisas Amazonia, Lab
   Genet Anim, Av Andre Araujo 2936, Manaus, Amazonas, BR-69067375 BC,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM valentim@inpa.gov.br
RI Porto, Jorge/K-1441-2014
OI Porto, Jorge/0000-0003-1393-6492; Gross, Maria
   Claudia/0000-0003-1161-238X
SC Zoology; Cell Biology; Genetics &Heredity; Environmental Sciences
   &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 0016-6707
BD Cytology; Protoplasm; Nucleus; Genetics; Cytogenetics; Habitat;
   Freshwater habitat; Lotic water; Land zones; Neotropical region; South
   America
DE Potamotrygon [Nucleolus / Nucleolus organizer region / ] [Sex
   determination genetics / XX/XO sex chromosome system / ] [Chromosomes / 
   / ] [River /  / ] [Brazil / Amazonas, Negro River / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Chondrichthyes, Elasmobranchii,
   Myliobatiformes, Potamotrygonidae

AN ZOOR15011062962
DT Article
TI Early Bartonian orthophragminids (Foraminiferida) from Reineche
   Limestone, north African platform, Tunisia: taxonomy and
   paleobiogeographic implications.
AU Ben Ismail-Lattrache, Kmar
   Ozcan, Ercan (ozcanerc@itu.edu.tr) 
   Boukhalfa, Kamel
   Saraswati, Pratul Kumar
   Soussi, Mohamed
   Jovane, Luigi
SO Geodinamica Acta
VL 26
IS 1-2
PS 94-121
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The orthophragminids in lower Bartonian Reineche Limestone member, a
   fossiliferous shallow-marine unit exposed in Cap Bon peninsula in
   Tunisia, are represented by 17 species assigned to Discocyclinidae
   Galloway 1928 and Orbitoclypeidae Bronnimann 1946. These taxa,
   associated with nummulitids and alveolinids, belong to the lineages of
   Discocyclina Gumbel 1870, Nemkovella, 1987, Orbitoclypeus Silvestri
   1907, and Asterocyclina Gumbel 1870, described for the first time from
   north Africa lying at the southern margin of Tethyan ocean during
   Paleogene. We identified Nemkovella evae, previously not recorded in
   upper Lutetian/lower Bartonian and younger Eocene deposits of northern
   Tethyan platforms, and erected a new subspecies, N. evae reinechensis n.
   ssp. A comparison of Reineche orthophraminids, assigned to
   orthophragmines zone (OZ) 12 and shallow benthic zone (SBZ 17), to the
   well-described coeval assemblages at northern Tethyan platforms in
   Italy, Hungary, Turkey, and to those in Kutch Basin in the Indian
   subcontinent suggests that some species are confined to certain
   paleogeographic domains. Orbitoclypeus haynesi, the only orbitoclypeid
   and the most abundant orthophragminid in lower Bartonian deposits in
   Kutch, appears to be the most common orbitoclypeid in Reineche
   Limestone. In Europe, this species is not known and is replaced by
   Orbitoclypeus varians, the most common orbitoclypeid in middle Eocene of
   central Europe. Both species occur in varying proportions in marine
   successions in Turkey. Asterocyclina sireli, identified so far only in
   Turkey, occurs in Reineche Limestone and in lower Bartonian deposits in
   Kutch. This species is recorded for the first time in the Indian
   subcontinent. Relying on present study, as well as our recent studies in
   Kutch Basin, we conclude that the generic and specific diversity of
   orthophragminids decreases eastward from the peri-Mediterranean region
   to Indian subcontinent and to the western Pacific.
C1 Ozcan, Ercan; Istanbul Tech Univ ITU, Dept Geol Engn, Istanbul,
   TR-34469, Turkey, Turkey.
EM ozcanerc@itu.edu.tr
RI Jovane, Luigi/E-7536-2012; Boukhalfa, Kamel/AAN-8474-2020; Kamel,
   Boukhalfa/AAF-5581-2020; Jovane, Luigi/AAH-5438-2020
OI Jovane, Luigi/0000-0003-4348-4714; Boukhalfa, Kamel/0000-0001-5115-565X;
   Jovane, Luigi/0000-0003-4348-4714; Soussi, Mohamed/0000-0001-7819-2231
SC Zoology
SN 0985-3111

   Palaearctic region; Africa; Eurasia; Asia; India; Geological time

PT J
AN ZOOR15102010832
DT Article
TI An array of sixth abdominal tergite types of paguroid anomurans
   (Crustacea) from the mid-Cretaceous of Navarra, northern Spain.
AU Fraaije, H.B. (info@oertijdmuseum.nl) 
   Artal, P.
   van Bakel, B.W.M.
   Jagt, J.W.M.
   Klompmaker, A.A.
SO Geologie en Mijnbouw
VL 92
IS 2-3
PS 109-117
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB In recent years, a range of operculate sixth abdominal tergite types of
   pylochelid and parapylochelid hermit crabs (Anomura, Paguroidea) have
   been recorded from Upper Jurassic (Oxfordian and Kimmeridgian) strata in
   southern Poland and southern Germany. Here we add two new genera
   (Parapylochelitergites, Paguritergites) and four new late Early
   Cretaceous species (Parapylochelitergites pustulosus, Pylochelitergites
   alatus, Pylochelitergites rugosus and Paguritergites yvonnecooleae) from
   Navarra, northern Spain. In the reefal limestones at Koskobilo quarry
   near Alsasua, of late Albian age, the number of sixth abdominal paguroid
   tergite taxa approximates that of paguroid carapace types. Thus, linking
   fossil paguroid carapaces to tergites can now be attempted. Assemblages
   of symmetrical hermit crabs (parapylochelids and pylochelids) in reefal
   settings appear to have changed drastically from the late Albian
   onwards, with asymmetrical forms (Diogenidae, Paguridae) becoming
   predominant.
C1 Fraaije, H.B.; Oertijdmuseum De Groene Poort, Bosscheweg 80, Boxtel,
   NL-5283 WB, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM info@oertijdmuseum.nl
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology

   Decapoda, Reptantia, Anomura

AN ZOOR15102010834
DT Article
TI Notes on selected Cretaceous echinoids from south-central Sakhalin, Far
   East Russia.
AU Jagt, J.W.M. (john.jagt@maastricht.nl) 
   Jagt-Yazykova, E.A.
   Zonova, T.D.
SO Geologie en Mijnbouw
VL 92
IS 2-3
PS 123-132
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB From Albian, Santonian and Campanian strata in south-central Sakhalin,
   four echinoid taxa are described, illustrated and discussed. In Far East
   Russia, echinoids are rare constituents amongst mid-and Late Cretaceous
   macrofaunal assemblages in which inoceramid and non-inoceramid bivalves,
   plus heteromorph and non-heteromorph ammonites predominate. The sole
   regular species in the present lot is represented by an incomplete
   external mould of a primary spine of a rhabdocidarid, Polycidaris(?)
   sp., from the lower Campanian. Irregular taxa include a fragmentary,
   specifically indeterminate 'pygurid', Echinopygus(?) sp., of late Albian
   age, as well as two spatangoids. One of these, a toxasterid of late
   Campanian age, is assigned to Niponaster cf. hokkaidensis (Lambert in
   Lambert & Thiery, 1924). The other is a new hemiasterid with a
   semi-ethmophract apical disc, a peripetalous fasciole with diffuse
   boundaries (parafasciole) and posterior petals that are near-equal in
   length to anterior ones, from lowermost Campanian strata. For this, the
   name Palhemiaster natalyae n. sp. is introduced. Comparisons with coeval
   echinoid faunas from nearby Hokkaido (northern Japan) are hampered by
   the generally poor preservation of the latter. However, with the
   exception of Niponaster cf. hokkaidensis, none of the forms recorded in
   the present paper appears to be represented in those Japanese
   assemblages.
C1 Jagt, J.W.M.; Nat Hist Museum Maastricht, Bosquetpl 6-7, Maastricht,
   NL-6211 KJ, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM john.jagt@maastricht.nl
RI Yazykova, Elena/D-5639-2018
OI Yazykova, Elena/0000-0002-6528-9875
SC Zoology
SN 0016-7746
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Echinoidea [Russia / Sakhalin Island / systematics] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Palhemiaster natalyae [Russia /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Echinoderms; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Echinodermata, Echinoidea
OR Echinoidea (Echinodermata): [Fossil]. 
   Palhemiaster natalyae (Echinoidea): [Sp nov, Russia, Cretaceous, P. 127;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15102010834

DT Article
TI Wardium mackoifusa sp n. (Cestoda, Cyclophyllidea), a parasite of the
   little gull (Larus minutus Pall.) from Ukraine.
AU Greben, O.B. (oksana-greben@yandex.ru) 
   Kornyushin, V.V.
SO Helminthologia (Bratislava)
VL 50
IS 3
PS 185-189
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The new cyclophyllidian species Wardium mackoifusa sp. n. (Aploparksidae
   Mayhew 1925), in the little gull (Larus minutus Pall.) from Ukraine is
   described. The species is characterized by 10 aploparaksoid hooks, each
   13-15 [mu]m long. It noticeably differs from all of the species of this
   genus by the shape and the armament of the cirrus and the presence of
   polar delicate filaments on the embryophore of eggs.
C1 Greben, O.B.; NAS Ukraine, Schmalhausen Inst Zool, 15 Khmelnitsky Str,
   Kiev, UA-01601, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM oksana-greben@yandex.ru

   Eurasia; Europe

PT J
AN ZOOR15309053539
DT Article
TI New record of insect pests attacking Butea monosperma - A commercial
   host for culturing lac insect, Kerria lacca (Kerr).
AU Singh, J.P.
   Jaiswal, A.K.
   Monobrullah, Md.
SO Indian Journal of Entomology
VL 75
IS 3
PS 225-231
PD September 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Butea monosperma is one of the major commercial lac hosts for raising
   rangeeni strain of Indian lac insect, Kerria lacca (Kerr). In changing
   climatic scenario, pest complex in lac production system is also
   changing. Comprehensive and intensive lac host plant surveillance and
   field collections of insect pests from commercial lac host, Butea
   monosperma (palas), the flame of forest trees carried out during last
   five years reveal the occurrence of some new pests. Scale insects namely
   Aulacaspis sp., (Hemiptera: Diaspididae) and Pseudaulacaspis cockerelli
   (Cooley) (Hemiptera: Diaspididae), sweet potato bug, Physomerus
   grossipes Fabricius (Hemiptera: Coreidae) as well as curculionids viz.,
   Myllocerus discolor Boheman (Coleoptera: Curculionidae); Amblyrrhinus
   poricollis Marshall (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) and Peltotrachelus sp.
   (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) were recorded for the first time from India
   on Butea monosperma. Interestingly some insect pests reported as minor
   and sporadic by earlier workers have been replaced by another species
   and its occurrence noticed regularly as in case of curculionids
   attacking commercial lac hosts. In recent past, it has been observed
   that those species which were not recognized as economically important
   have now become major pests and vice-versa. Considerable variations in
   their period of occurrence and activity have also been noticed.
C1 Singh, J.P.; Indian Institute of Natural Resins and Gums, Ranchi,
   Jharkhand, India, India.
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 0367-8288
BD Nutrition; Diet; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Amblyrrhinus poricollis; Aulacaspis; Myllocerus discolor; Peltotrachelus
   [Plant hosts / Butea monosperma / New record] [India /  / ] [Jharkhand /
    / ]. 
   Physomerus grossipes; Pseudaulacaspis cockerelli [Food plants / Butea
   monosperma / New record] [India /  / ] [Jharkhand /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae, Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Pentatomomorpha, Coreoidea,
   Coreidae, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha, Coccoidea

   Peltotrachelus (Curculionidae): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Physomerus grossipes (Coreidae): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15206037179
DT Article
TI Natural enemy complex associated with the mealybug, Phenacoccus
   solenopsis Tinsley (Hemiptera: Pseudococcidae) infesting different host
   plants in India.
AU Suroshe, Sachin S.
   Gautam, R.D.
   Fand, Babasaheb B. (babasahebfand@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of Biological Control
VL 27
IS 3
PS 204-210
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Recently, Indian cotton belt experienced a devastating outbreak of
   Phenacoccus solenopsis Tinsley. Natural enemy complex associated with P.
   solenopsis was explored by conducting extensive field surveys coupled
   with laboratory screening of samples collected from various localities
   across the country. A total of seventeen parasitoids inclusive of
   hyperparasitoids were identified. An encyrtid, Aenasius bambawalei
   Hayat, was found predominantly on P. solenopsis. Promuscidea
   unfasciativentris Girault predominated the hyperparasitic fauna.
   Interestingly, Aphanogmus sp. and Anastatus sp. were recorded for the
   first time on P. solenopsis. Additionally, eight species of
   Coccinellidae and two species of Chrysopidae were recovered as important
   predators.
C1 Fand, Babasaheb B.; Indian Agr Res Inst ICAR, Biol Control Lab, New
   Delhi, 110012, India, India.
EM babasahebfand@gmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0970-5732

   Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Ecology; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Anastatus; Aphanogmus [Hemipteran hosts / Phenacoccus solenopsis / New
   record] [India /  / ]. 
   Phenacoccus solenopsis [Biological control /  / hyperparasitism;
   parasite diversity; survey] [Parasites /  / ] [Hymenopteran parasites /
   Anastatus / New record] [ / Aphanogmus / ] [Plant hosts /  / ]
   [Predators /  / ] [India /  / ] [Andhra Pradesh /  / ] [Delhi /  / ]
   [Maharashtra /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs

   Proctotrupoidea, Ceraphronidae
OR Phenacoccus solenopsis (Coccoidea): [Host; New record]. 
   Anastatus (Eupelmidae): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Aphanogmus (Ceraphronidae): [Parasite; New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15206037180
DT Article
TI Evaluation of some microbial pesticides against apple stem borer,
   Aeolesthes sp in Himachal Pradesh.
AU Chauhan, Usha (uchauhan97@rediffmail.com) 
   Sharma, P.L.
   Gupta, P.R.
   Sharma, K.C.
   Verma, S.P.
SO Journal of Biological Control
VL 27
IS 3
PS 211-213
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Apple stem borer, Aeolesthes sp. is a serious pest in apple orchards in
   Himachal Pradesh. For its suppression, microbial biopesticides viz.,
   Beauveria bassiana, Beauveria brongniarti, Metarhizium anisopliae (5 x
   107 conidia/gallery), Steinernema feltiae, Heterorhabditis bacteriophora
   (5000 infective juveniles (IJ)/ live gallery) and econeem plus (having
   1% azadirachtin @ 0.5%) were evaluated. The experiment was conducted for
   two years during 2007-08 and 2008-09 at Temperate Horticulture Research
   station, Kotkhai, District Shimla. These biopesticides were compared
   with the recommended insecticides, dichlorvos (0.1%) and chlorpyriphos
   (0.04%) and control (emulsified water, 0.02%). Before applying the
   treatments, all the holes except one present in each branch were plugged
   with mud paste. The leftover hole was then cleared with the help of
   flexible aluminium wire and the treatment was given with the help of
   syringe. Thereafter, the leftover hole was also plugged with mud paste.
   To calculate percent mortality, the larvae which opened any of the holes
   in the branch or made new hole to push out the excreta were considered
   as live and those which remained closed throughout as dead. In this
   experiment, B. bassiana, B. brongniartii, M. anisopliae, H.
   bacteriophora, S. feltiae, econeem, chlorpyriphos, dichlorvos and
   control resulted in 33.3, 66.7, 37.5, 80, 20, 100, 100, 100 and 40
   percent mortality during 2007-08 and 33.3, 33.3, 66.7, 33.3, 33.3, 66.7,
   100, 100 and 0.00 per cent mortality during 2008-09 respectively. Among
   different biopesticides, M. anisopliae, B. brongniartii and cconeem plus
   were the best treatments resulting in 66.7 and 100 per cent mortality of
   stem borer larvae
C1 Chauhan, Usha; Dr YS Parmar Univ Hort & Forestry, Dept Entomol &
   Apiculture, Solan, Himachal Pradesh, 173230, India, India.
EM uchauhan97@rediffmail.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Nutrition &Dietetics;
   Parasitology; Mycology; Infectious Diseases
SN 0970-5732
BD Animals and man; Control; Nutrition; Diet; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Diseases
   and disorders; Microbial diseases; Ecology; Population dynamics;
   Habitat; Man made habitat; Abiotic factors; Chemical factors; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Aeolesthes [Biological control /  / ] [Food plants / Apple plant / ]
   [Nematode parasites / Heterorhabditis bacteriophora / ] [ / Steinernema
   feltiae / ] [Fungal diseases / Beauveria bassiana / ] [ / Beauveria
   brongniarti / ] [ / Metarhizium anisopliae / ] [Mortality /  / ]
   [Cultivated land habitat / Apple orchards / ] [Fertilizers and
   pesticides /  / ] [Himachal Pradesh / Shimla, Kotkhai / ]. 
   Heterorhabditis bacteriophora; Steinernema feltiae [Biological control /
   / ] [Coleopteran hosts / Aeolesthes / ] [Cultivated land habitat / Apple
   orchards / ] [Himachal Pradesh / Shimla, Kotkhai / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae, Nematoda
OR Aeolesthes (Cerambycidae): [Host]. 
   Heterorhabditis bacteriophora (Nematoda): [Parasite]. 
   Steinernema feltiae (Nematoda): [Parasite].

   description of a new species from Southern Western Ghats, Kerala
   (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Pteromalidae).
AU Sureshan, P.M. (pmsuresh43@yahoo.com) 
   Nikhil, K.
SO Journal of Entomological Research (New Delhi)
VL 37
IS 3
PS 273-276
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Miscogasteriella Girault (Hymenoptera: Pteromalidae)
   viz., M. bijoyi sp. nov. has been described from Southern Western Ghats,
   Kerala, India and the species M. jayasreeae Sureshan is reported from
   Kerala subsequent to the original description in 1997. Affinities of the
   new species with related species are discussed and a key to the Indian
   species of Miscogasteriella is also provided.

PM 24115782
DT Article
TI Taxonomic and Molecular Identification of Hemicaloosia, Hemicycliophora,
   Gracilacus and Paratylenchus Species (Nematoda: Criconematidae).
AU Cordero Lopez, Marco A. (mcordero@uark.edu) 
   Robbins, Robert T.
   Szalanski, Allen L.
SO Journal of Nematology
VL 45
IS 3
PS 145-171
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Populations of Hemicycliophora epicharoides, H. gigas, H. labiata, H.
   pruni, H. shepherdi, H. vidua, H. zuckermani, Gracilacus straeleni, and
   Paratylenchus labiosus were obtained from different geographical areas
   in the continental United States and characterized morphological and
   molecularly. Two new species of Hemicycliophorinae: Hemicaloosia uarki
   n. sp from Pinetree, St. Francis County, Arkansas, and Hemicycliophora
   wyei n. sp from Wayne County, North Carolina, are also described.
   Hemicaloosia uarki n. sp. is characterized by having two lip annuli
   separated from the rest of body and directed anteriorly, a long stylet
   (106-124 [mu]m), long body length (1,081-1,326 [mu]m) and a single
   lateral fields demarcated by interruptions of the body annuli.
   Hemicycliophora wyei n. sp. showed a lateral fields demarked by two
   faint lines with transverse anastomoses and/or breaks of the striae; an
   elongated not offset conical tail with distinct annulations and a
   rounded tip and long vulval lips with a vulval sleeve. The molecular
   characterizations of the new (H. uarki n. sp. and H. wyei n. sp.) and
   known species of Criconematidae using the ITS1 rDNA gene sequence and
   the molecular phylogenetic relationships are provided.
C1 Cordero Lopez, Marco A.; Univ Arkansas, Dept Plant Pathol, 2601 N Young
   Ave, Fayetteville, AR, 72704, USA, USA.
EM mcordero@uark.edu
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0022-300X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Genetics;
   Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Gracilacus; Hemicaloosia; Hemicycliophora; Paratylenchus [General
   morphology /  / systematics] [Molecular genetics / Molecular
   identification / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [USA /  / ]. 
   Hemicaloosia uarki [Arkansas /  / New species]. 
   Hemicycliophora wyei [North Carolina /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Gracilacus - Raski 1962 (Nematoda). 
   Hemicaloosia - Ray & Das 1978 (Nematoda). 
   Hemicaloosia uarki (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Arkansas, P. 146]. 
   Hemicycliophora - de Man 1921 (Nematoda). 
   Hemicycliophora wyei (Nematoda): [Sp nov, North Carolina, P. 150]. 
   Paratylenchus - Micoletzky 1922 (Nematoda).

TI New Radiolaria of the family Pseudodictyomitridae from the
   Coniacian-Santonian of the Perapedhi Formation of southern Cyprus.
AU Bragina, L.G. (l.g.bragina@mail.ru) 
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 47
IS 5
PS 457-462
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new genus of Late Cretaceous radiolarians, Cyprodictyomitra gen. nov.,
   comprising two new species, C. longa sp. nov., C. elegantissima sp.
   nov., and a new species, Pseudodictyomitra crassa sp. nov. are
   described. These new taxa come from rich Coniacian-Santonian radiolarian
   associations of the Perapedhi Formation of Southern Cyprus.

TI New species of the Inoceramus-like bivalve genus Maitaia Marwick from
   the Permian of northeastern Asia.
AU Biakov, A.S. (abiakov@mail.ru) 
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 47
IS 5
PS 463-469
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Historical development of Permian Inoceramus-like bivalves of the
   bipolar genus Maitaia Marwick in northeastern Asia is briefly
   considered. Five new species (Maitaia vedernikovi sp. nov., M. kusnezovi
   sp. nov., M. orulganica sp. nov., M. regularicostatum sp. nov., and M.
   tobonnoensis sp. nov.) from the Middle and Upper Permian of the Omolon
   Massif, northern, western, and southern Verkhoyansk Region are
   described.

DT Article
TI A new anobasicrinid (Crinoidea, Cladida) from the Upper Carboniferous of
   the Moscow Region.
AU Mirantsev, G.V. (GMirantsev@gmail.com) 
   Arendt, Yu. A.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 47
IS 5
PS 470-479
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new anobasicrinid genus and species, Parasciadiocrinus lancetospinosus
   gen. et sp. nov. (Crinoidea, Cladida), is described from the Upper
   Carboniferous of the Moscow Region. The new genus and Sciadiocrinus
   Moore et Plummer, 1940 together form a separate branch of
   anobasicrinids, which is similar to pirasocrinids through parallel
   evolution. The differences between these two groups are discussed in
   detail.

TI Gryllolattids (Insecta, Grylloblattida) from the Upper Permian of South

   Mostovski, M.B.

VL 47

PS 495-502
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A Late Permian fauna of grylloblattid insects (Insecta; Grylloblattida)
   from the KwaZulu-Natal Province (South Africa) is considered. New taxa,
   Liomopterites ulterior sp. nov. and L. meridionalis sp. nov. (family
   Liomopteridae); Normandienoptera serotina gen. et sp. nov. and
   Afrogrylloblattus disputabilis gen. et sp. nov. (Skaliciidae), are
   described. Mioloptera stuckenbergi Riek, 1973 and Mioloptoides andrei
   Riek, 1976 of the family Liomopteridae are redescribed.

DT Article
TI New data on osteostracans (Agnatha) from the Lower Devonian of the
   Severnaya Zemlya Archipelago.
AU Afanassieva, O.B. (oafan@paleo.ru) 
   Karatajute-Talimaa, V.N.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 47
IS 5
PS 513-522
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The osteostracans Reticulaspis menneri gen. et sp. nov. and Nucleaspis
   unica gen. et sp. nov. from the Lower Devonian Severnaya Zemlya
   Formation of October Revolution Island of the Severnaya Zemlya
   Archipelago are described. The perfect preservation of the exoskeleton
   structure of Reticulaspis menneri allows the design and growth mode of
   the exoskeleton, with a continuous reticular dental surface of the
   cephalothoracic shield to be characterized. Nucleaspis unica is
   represented by a juvenile stage, which is extremely scarce in this
   vertebrate group. The preoccupied generic name Ungulaspis Afanassieva et
   Karatajute-Talimaa, 1998 is replaced by Paraungulaspis.
C1 Afanassieva, O.B.; Russian Acad Sci, Borissiak Paleontol Inst,
   Profsoyuznaya Ul 123, Moscow, 117997, Russia, Russia.

SO Paleontological Journal
VL 47
IS 5
PS 523-532
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Based on the analysis of skull and postcranial morphology, the species
   Clupea doljeana Kramberger, 1884, Illusionella tsurevica Baykina, 2012,
   and I. pshekhensis Baykina, 2012 are transferred to the genus Sarmatella
   Menner, 1949. Emended descriptions of Clupea doljeana Kramberger, 1884
   and Sarmatella vukotinovici (Kramberger, 1884) are provided. The genus
   Illusionella Baykina, 2012 is synonymized under Sarmatella Menner, 1949.

DT Article
TI A new genus and two new species of Tortricidae (Lepidoptera) from the
   Canary Islands.
AU Larsen, Knud (knud.torts@gmail.com) 
SO Phegea
VL 41
IS 3
PS 50-54
PD Sep 1 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper the new genus Willibaldiana is described. The description
   of the new genus is based upon material collected at the Island
   Fuerteventura, part of the archipelago of the Canary Islands, Spain. The
   material consists of two species both of them new to science. All the
   material is collected from the same light trap stationed at a summer
   house at the southern tip of Fuerteventura - Barranco Esquinzo, Jandia.
   It is rather remarkable to find two new species belonging to the same
   new genus at the same locality. It is suggested that these taxa are
   belonging to very old Mediterranean taxa that have survived and
   developed in the semi desert environment of Fuerteventura. The new genus
   is placed in Eucosmini after Clavigesta Obraztsov, 1946. The names of
   the two new species are Willibaldiana paasi n. sp. and Willibaldiana
   schmitzi n. sp. Holotypes and paratypes are deposited in the author's
   collection.
C1 Larsen, Knud; Rontoftevej 33, Dyssegaard, DK-2870, Denmark, Denmark.
EM knud.torts@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0771-5277
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oceanic islands;
   Atlantic Ocean islands
DE Willibaldiana paasi; Willibaldiana schmitzi [Canary Islands /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Tortricoidea, Tortricidae
OR Willibaldiana (Tortricidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Eucosmini, Type species
   Willibaldiana paasi, p. 51]. 
   Willibaldiana paasi (Tortricidae): [Sp nov, Canary Islands, P. 51]. 
   Willibaldiana schmitzi (Tortricidae): [Sp nov, Canary Islands, P. 52].

DT Article
TI VISEAN CORALS OF THE KIYASAR AREA, SOUTH OF SARI, NORTHERN IRAN.
AU Ogar, Victor (ogar_victor@ukr.net) 
   Falahatgar, Mostafa
   Mosaddegh, Hossein
SO Revista Brasileira de Paleontologia
VL 16
IS 3
PS 375-396
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Corals from the middle part of the Mobarak Formation, exposed in the
   Kiyasar area of northern Iran, were examined for descriptions, age
   determination and indications of the paleoenvironment. New genera for
   the families Adamanophyllidae and Clisiophyllidae/ Amygdalophyllinae
   were established and three new species were described for the
   Bifossularia, Clisiophyllum and Spirophyllum genera. The age of studied
   corals is generally consistent with the early-middle Visean as
   previously was determined based on foraminifera. The absence of colonial
   rugose and syringoporid is a notable feature of these coral communities.

PT J

DT Article
TI REVISION OF LATE CENOZOIC HYOTISSA (BIVALVIA: PYCNODONTEINAE) FROM
   WESTERN NORTH AMERICA.
AU Cristin, Alejandro (alcris@unam.mx) 
   Perrilliat, Maria del Carmen
SO Revista Brasileira de Paleontologia
VL 16
IS 3
PS 397-426
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 15
AB Some Neogene Pycnodonte species, related to the ancient Gulf of
   California and coastal California, are morphologically similar to
   Hyotissa hyotis (Linnaeus), the living honeycomb oyster. Morphological
   variation in these species or in H. hyotis has never been studied. In
   order to document variation and use the results to detect a possible
   taxonomic overspliting, the present authors described the morphology and
   morphometry of fossil shells of H. hyotis from the early Pleistocene
   Loreto Basin, Baja California Sur, Mexico. It was compared with type and
   non-type specimens from the Early Miocene Vaqueros sandstone (coastal
   California), Late Miocene rocks of Isla Tiburon (Gulf of California),
   Pliocene Imperial Formation (southern California) and Pleistocene rocks
   in Loreto area (Gulf of California). The specimens from coastal
   California and Isla Tiburon were re-assigned to a new genus, and to
   Hyotissa cf. H. hyotis; and synonymized P. (Pycnodonte) heermanni
   (Conrad) from southern California with H. hyotis. With this new
   information, the fossil record of Hyotissa in western America ranges
   from Early Miocene to Recent; H. hyotis lived through the whole ancient
   Gulf of California during the Pliocene, contrary to the current
   distribution in the modern gulf. Finally, Hyotissa species exhibit a
   little variable morphology, which is contrary to traditional views,
   complicating Pycnodonteinae taxonomy and classification.
C1 Cristin, Alejandro; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Inst Geol, Mexico City,
   DF, 04510, Mexico, Mexico.
EM alcris@unam.mx
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Paleontology
SN 1519-7530
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Biometrics; Skeletal and
   supporting structures; Shell; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary; Tertiary;
   Neogene
DE Hyotissa [North America / West / systematics] [Caenozoic / Late
   Caenozoic / ]. 
   Hyotissa hyotis [Biometrics / Morphometrics / systematics] [Shell
   morphology /  / ] [Mexico / Baja California Sur, Loreto Basin / ]
   [Pleistocene / Early Pleistocene / ]. 
   Orrstreidi [Miocene /  / New genus].

   Hyotissa hyotis - (Linnaeus 1758) (Ostreoidea): [Senior synonym, Of
   Pycnodonte (Pycnodonte) heerrnanni (Conrad 1855), p. 397; Fossil].

DT Article
TI ANNOTATED CHECKLIST OF SPONGES (PORIFERA) FROM THE SOUTHERNMOST
   CARIBBEAN REEFS (NORTH-WEST GULF OF URABA), WITH DESCRIPTION OF NEW
   RECORDS FOR THE COLOMBIAN CARIBBEAN.
AU Valderrama, Diego (diego.valderrama.bio@gmail.com) 
   Zea, Sven
SO Revista de la Academia Colombiana de Ciencias Exactas Fisicas y
   Naturales
VL 37
IS 144
PS 353-378
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The North-West Gulf of Uraba, Colombia, harbors the southernmost
   Caribbean reefs, exposed to high turbulence and fluctuating turbidity
   and salinity. An annotated systematic check-list of sponges from this
   area is presented. A total of 77 demosponge species (class
   Demospongiae), 3 homoscleromorph species (class Homoscleromorpha) and 1
   calcareous species (class Calcarea) were found to inhabit rocky shores
   and reefs, above 20 m in depth. Some species in Uraba bear siliceous
   spicules larger than in other Caribbean areas, probably owing to
   additional silicon input from heavy river discharge in the gulf. This
   work provides, additionally, the formal taxonomic description of 15
   species, which are new records for the Colombian Caribbean.
C1 Valderrama, Diego; UFBA UEFS, Programa Posgrad Ensino Filosofia & Hist
   Ciencias, Salvador, BA, Brazil, Brazil.
EM diego.valderrama.bio@gmail.com

SN 0370-3908

   Documentation; Publications; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic
DE Porifera [Checklists / Annotated taxonomic checklist / New record;
   Colombia; Gulf of Uraba] [Caribbean Sea / Colombia, Gulf of Uraba / ].

ST Animalia, Porifera, Demospongiae

   [Referred to, Svenzea, p. 369].

PT J

DT Article
TI Discovery of dinosaur footprints from Ningxia and its significance.
AU Zong, Li-yi
   Lu, Jun-chang
   Wen, Wan-cheng
   Yang, Qing
   Wan, Yang
SO Shijie Dizhi
VL 32
IS 3
PS 427-436
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The first discovery of dinosaur footprints from Guyuan of Ningxia is
   briefly reported. These dinosaur footprints include the ornithopod and
   the sauropod dinosaur footprints. All of them are found in the Early
   Cretaceous deposits of Liwaxia Formation. The ornithopod dinosaur
   footprint is named as Ningxiapus liupanshanensis ichnogen et inchnosp.
   nov. It is characterized by the ratio of length to width 1.22, the first
   toe slender, shorter than the fourth toe, the angle between the second
   and the third toes 35[degree], and the angle between the third and
   fourth 45[degree] also. The sauropod dinosaur preserved their tracks
   also. Their manus and footprints are 36 cm and 15 cm long respectively,
   which implies that they were left by mid-sized sauropod dinosaurs. The
   discovery of these footprints provides important information on
   reconstruction of paleobiogeography and paleoecology, and the discovery
   is very significant for searching of the dinosaur bones from this area
   in the near future.
C1 Zong, Li-yi; Ningxia Geol Museum, Yinchuan, 750011, China, China.
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 1004-5589
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Fossil traces; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Fossil Miscellanea [Fossil tracks / Fossil footprints / Attributed to
   Ornithopoda (Reptilia); morphology] [ /  / Attributed to Sauropoda
   (Reptilia); tracemaker identity; new record; systematics] [Ningxia Hui /
   Guyuan / fossil footprints attributed to Ornithopoda (Reptilia)] [ /  /
   fossil footprints attributed to Sauropoda (Reptilia)] [Cretaceous /
   Early Cretaceous / ] [ /  / ]. 
   Ningxiapus [Fossil tracks / New genus possibly attributable to
   Ornithopoda (Reptilia), Cretaceous / ] [Cretaceous /  / New genus
   described from fossil track; Possibly attributable to Ornithopoda
   (Reptilia)]. 
   Ningxiapus liupanshanensis [Fossil tracks / New species possibly

PT J
AN ZOOR15412088722
DT Article
TI A new gigantic sauropod dinosaur from the Middle Jurassic of Shanshan,
   Xinjiang.
AU Wu, Wen-hao
   Zhou, Chang-fu
   Wings, Oliver
   Sekiya, Toru
   Dong, Zhi-ming
SO Shijie Dizhi
VL 32
IS 3
PS 437-446
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new gigantic sauropod dinosaur, Xinjiangtitan shanshanesis gen. et sp.
   nov. is reported with preliminary descriptions. It is well preserved in
   situ and discovered from the Middle Jurassic Qigu Formtion in Shanshan
   of Xinjiang for the first time. Xinjiangtitan (gen. nov.) is
   characterized by a ventral keel developed on the penultimated cervical
   centrum and formed a small semi-circular process under the distal
   articular facet, last two cervical vertebrae are particularly elongated
   (ratio "length of the last two cervical vertebrae / length of femur and
   tibia" is 0.63), sacricostal yoke excepting the first sacral rib, and
   extremely robust femur (ratio "transverse width of the distal end /
   femur length" is 0.33). Cladistic analysis places Xinjiangtitan as the
   sister group of Mamenchisaurus. Xinjiangtitan is definitely a new taxon
   of mamenchisaurid dinosaur. However, Xinjiangtitan developed several
   diplodocid-like characters: prominent ambiens process of pubis,
   relatively short hind limb and caudomedially developed fourth trochanter
   on femoral body. The total body length of Xinjiangtitan is calculated as
   30 - 32 meters.
C1 Wu, Wen-hao; Jilin Univ, Res Ctr Paleontol & Stratig, Changchun, Jilin,
   130026, China, China.
SC Zoology
SN 1004-5589
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Xinjiangtitan [Jurassic /  / New genus]. 
   Xinjiangtitan shanshanesis [Xinjiang Uygur /  / new species] [Jurassic /
    / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Saurischia,
   Sauropodomorpha
OR Xinjiangtitan (Sauropodomorpha): [Gen nov, Of family Mamenchisauridae,
   Type species Xinjiangtitan shanshanesis, p. 439, Jurassic; Fossil]. 
   Xinjiangtitan shanshanesis (Sauropodomorpha): [Sp nov, Xinjiang Uygur,
   Jurassic, P. 439; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15412088722
DA 2020-09-17

PM 23949651
DT Article
TI Description of Rhabdias breviensis n. sp (Rhabditoidea: Rhabdiasidae) in
   two Neotropical frog species.
AU Silva do Nascimento, Luciana de Cassia
   Goncalves, Evonnildo Costa
   de Vasconcelos Melo, Francisco Tiago
   Giese, Elane Guerreiro
   Furtado, Adriano Penha
   dos Santos, Jeannie Nascimento (jeannie@ufpa.br) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 86
IS 1
PS 69-75
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 15
AB Nematodes of the genus Rhabdias Stiles & Hassall, 1905 (Rhabditoidea:
   Rhabdiasidae) have a dioecious free-living stage and a hermaphroditic
   stage that parasitises the lungs of amphibians and reptiles.
   Approximately 94 species of Rhabdias have been described. Because the
   similar morphological characteristics such as the labial structures, the
   location of the vulva and the shape of the tail of Rhabdias spp. hinder
   their identification, molecular biology techniques and scanning electron
   microscopy have been employed to diagnose species of this genus. This
   study describes Rhabdias breviensis n. sp., parasitic in the lungs of
   two Neotropical frog species Leptodactylus petersii Steindachner and
   Leptodactylus macrosternum Miranda-Ribeiro. The description of this
   species integrates classical taxonomy, scanning electron microscopy and
   a molecular analysis of the mitochondrial COI gene. The new species
   differs from all other Rhabdias species parasitic in Neotropical hosts
   in certain morphometric parameters, the position of the vulva, the host
   group and the cephalic characters.
C1 dos Santos, Jeannie Nascimento; Univ Fed Para UFPA, Inst Ciencias Biol,
   Belem, Para, BR-66075110 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM jeannie@ufpa.br
RI Vasconcelos Melo, Francisco Tiago/O-5419-2018; Melo, Francisco Tiago
   V/I-2974-2015; NASCIMENTO DOS SANTOS, JEANNIE/F-7130-2012
OI Vasconcelos Melo, Francisco Tiago/0000-0001-8935-2923; Melo, Francisco
   Tiago V/0000-0001-8935-2923; NASCIMENTO DOS SANTOS,
   JEANNIE/0000-0002-6612-6410
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0165-5752
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Leptodactylus macrosternum; Leptodactylus petersii [Nematode parasites /
   Rhabdias breviensis / New parasite species] [Brazil /  / New nematode
   parasite species]. 
   Rhabdias breviensis [Amphibian hosts / Leptodactylus macrosternum / New
   parasite species] [ / Leptodactylus petersii / ] [Brazil /  / New
   species from amphibian host]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Invertebrates; Nematodes; Vertebrates

   Leptodactylidae, Nematoda

AN ZOOR15001000603
DT Article
TI Apistogramma aguarico sp n.: A new species of geophagine cichlid fish
   (Teleostei: Perciformes) from the Ecuadorian and Peruvian rio Napo
   system.
AU Roemer, Uwe (u.roemer@t-online.de) 
   Hahn, Ingo
SO Vertebrate Zoology
VL 63
IS 2
PS 171-181
PD September 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 13
AB A new species of Apistogramma, Apistogramma aguarico sp. n., is
   described from Ecuador, based on a total of 9 specimens collected from
   an oxbow lake (appr. 09[degree]47' S / 75[degree] 57' W) connected to
   the Rio Lagartococha, an affluent of the Rio Aguarico, which is part of
   the Rio Napo system in the north east of Ecuador close to the border
   with Peru. Apistogramma aguarico sp. n. is distinguished from all other
   Apistogramma species by the combination (in adult males) of: truncate
   unmarked caudal fin with streamer-like extensions to both upper and
   lower lobes in large individuals; four irregular abdominal lines formed
   by series of highly variable spots; serrate dorsal fin with membranes
   clearly prolonged past tips of spines; and ivory spot surrounding and
   including pectoral-fin base. The species is thought to be a
   representative of the Apistogramma eunotus complex within the
   Apistogramma regani lineage.
C1 Roemer, Uwe; Univ Trier, Inst Biogeog, Trier, D-54286, Germany, Germany.
EM u.roemer@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 1864-5755
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Apistogramma aguarico [Ecuador /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Cichlidae
OR Apistogramma aguarico (Cichlidae): [Sp nov, Ecuador, P. 172]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15001000603
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF EUPOLYMNIPHILUS (COPEPODA: CYCLOPOIDA: SABELLIPHILIDAE)
   FROM AN ANCHIALINE CAVE OF THE MEDITERRANEAN SEA WITH A KEY TO THE SEVEN
   SPECIES OF THE GENUS.
AU Costanzo, G.
   Brugnano, C. (cinzia.brugnano@unime.it) 
   Zagami, G.
SO Vie et Milieu
VL 63
IS 2
PS 75-80
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species belonging to the genus Eupolymniphilus (Sabelliphilidae)
   is described from an anchialine cave located on the southern coast of
   the Tyrrhenian Sea (Central Mediterranean). Among the six species
   recognized in the genus, the new species E. mediterraneus sp. nov. is
   most closely related to E. orientalis, E. brevicaudatus and E.
   occidentalis in sharing the following characters: proximal caudal seta
   swollen proximally, antennal second segment with pointed outer distal
   corner, and mandible with 1 scale on convex side. A comparison with the
   most closely related species reveals that the new species differs in
   total body length and in length/width ratio of the caudal ramus. The
   total body length is 0.75 mm and the caudal ramus is 3.0:1 times longer
   than wide, whereas in E. orientalis, E. brevicaudatus and E.
   occidentalis, the abovementioned characters are: 0.88-1.04 mm, 1.50:1;
   1.03 mm, 1:1; and 1.17-1.21 mm, 2.69:1, respectively.
C1 Brugnano, C.; Univ Messina, Dept Anim Biol & Marine Ecol, Viale F Stagno
   dAlcontres 31, Messina, I-98166, Italy, Italy.
EM cinzia.brugnano@unime.it
RI Brugnano, Cinzia/AAE-5354-2019

SN 0240-8759

   Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic

   75].

DT Article
TI A new species of Neopleistocene wolf (Canis subtilis).
AU Ovodov, N.D. (ndovodov@mail.ru) 
SO Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 92
IS 9
PS 1136-1141
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 9
AB The new species of the gray wolf, Canis subtilis (N. Ov.), from the Cave
   of Fanatiks (Khakasia) was first described based on measurements of its
   skull and lower jaw. The data obtained are compared to those on skulls
   and lower jaws of Pleistocene gray wolves from the Razboinich'ya Cave in
   the northwestern Altai. The bone remains of Canis subtilis were found in
   two caves of southern Siberia-Razboynich'ya Cave in the northwestern
   Altai and Belyi Gorod near Krasnoyarsk. The age of the findings is the
   Middle Late Neopleistocene. Based on the proportions of the skull and
   morphology of the teeth, slender wolf is suggested to use another, "fox"
   type of hunting. Probably, it moved more slowly than Canis lupus.
C1 Ovodov, N.D.; Russian Acad Sci, Siberian Branch, Novosibirsk, 630090,
   Russia, Russia.
EM ndovodov@mail.ru
SC Zoology; Paleontology

   region; Eurasia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary

PT J
AN ZOOR15010052228
DT Article
TI Origin of five unique Mite-Genera in geological periods compared to
   other groups of Gamasina (Acarina, Parasitiformes) and description of
   two new species of Rykellus Lee and Oloopticus Karg.
AU Karg, Wolfgang (Udo.Karg@arcor.de) 
   Schorlemmer, Anita
SO Zoosystematics and Evolution
VL 89
IS 2
PS 193-207
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 1
U2 8
AB At the centre of our investigation are the five genera Africoseius
   Krantz, 1962, Afrogamasellus Loots et Ryke, 1968, Rykellus Lee, 1970,
   Laelaspisella Marias et Loots, 1969 and Oloopticus Karg, 1978. These
   genera are distinguished by their extraordinary distribution in Africa
   and South America. We detected relations between the origin of these
   genera and the development of the earth's continents. These five genera
   must have developed during a geological period when the African and the
   South American continents were still connected, but separate from the
   other continents. The five genera belong to different super families and
   families of Gamasina. Within these groups, the cited genera are
   distinguished by extraordinary organ-formations in relation to their
   primary groups. Further, we identified genera that are with high
   probability the sister genera of the investigated five genera in
   agreement with the progression rule explained by W. Hennig. We also
   discuss the question, what time frames within geological periods are
   necessary for the development of higher categories, such as genera,
   families and even cohorts. The development of the five genera named
   above is placed at an estimated range of 20 to 30 million years. Results
   of investigations from the Galapagos Archipel and an island of the
   Lesser Antilles showed that within 4 million years new species
   developed, but no new genera. The family Leptolaelapidae Karg which
   includes 11 genera with 42 species are distributed over Sub Antarctic,
   South Africa, South America, Malaysia and Australia. These continents
   formed during the Mid Jurassic to the upper of Cretaceous period the
   Gondwanian super-continent. This means, a period of 60 to 80 million
   years was necessary to allow the development of this mite family.
   Corresponding findings refer to the Ologamasidae and, Trigynaspida. The
   origin of higher systematic categories, such as super-families and
   cohorts, has to be attributed to the oversized continent Pangaea.
   Several systematic groups, which are today distributed worldwide,
   already existed in the Permian and Triassic. Regarding the
   Parasitiformes the following groups of soil mites are significant:
   Gamasina, and Margotrichina. The subsequent gradual splitting of the
   Pangaea continent over 150 to 160 million years forced the development
   of these ancient higher systematic groups. Finally, we revise the
   subfamily Hypoaspidinae, the genera Oloopticus Karg, Laelaspisella
   Marais et Loots and Rykellus Lee including two new species and complete
   it with keys for 9 genera and 20 species. ([copyright] 2013 WILEY-VCH
   Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim)
C1 Karg, Wolfgang; Hohe Kiefer 152, Kleinmachnow, D-14532, Germany,
   Germany.
EM Udo.Karg@arcor.de
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Evolution;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Neotropical region;
   Africa; South America
DE Africoseius; Afrogamasellus; Laelaspisella; Oloopticus; Rykellus [Origin
   of taxon /  / ] [Zoogeography / Palaeozoogeography / ]. 
   Oloopticus africanus [Tanzania /  / New species]. 
   Rykellus ovalis [Paraguay /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Africoseius (Acari). 
   Afrogamasellus (Acari). 
   Hypoaspidinae (Acari): [Key to genera, P. 202]. 
   Laelaspisella - Marais & Loots 1969 (Acari): [Key to species, P. 203]. 
   Oloopticus - Karg 1978 (Acari): [Key to species, Females, p. 201]. 
   Oloopticus africanus (Acari): [Sp nov, Tanzania, P. 200]. 
   Rykellus - Lee 1970 (Acari): [Key to species, Females, p. 204]. 
   Rykellus ovalis (Acari): [Sp nov, Paraguay, P. 204]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15010052228
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15010052232
DT Article
TI Description of a new leech species from North America, Helobdella
   austinensis n. sp. (Hirudinea: Glossiphoniidae), with observations on
   its feeding behaviour.
AU Kutschera, U. (kut@uni-kassel.de) 
   Langguth, H.
   Kuo, D.-H.
   Weisblat, D.A.
   Shankland, M.
SO Zoosystematics and Evolution
VL 89
IS 2
PS 239-246
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Freshwater leeches of the genus Helobdella Blanchard 1896 are small,
   proboscis-bearing glossiphoniids of the family Rhynchobdellidae that
   have been found worldwide. Over the past three decades, annelid
   developmental biologists have used several Helobdella species as model
   organisms. Here we describe a variable taxon, that has been studied
   extensively, and was formerly labelled as Helobdella sp. "robusta
   (Austin), as a new species, Helobdella austinensis n. sp. Diagnostic
   features of this polymorphic species, which has a body length of 13 to
   17 mm and a yellow-brown colour, include a characteristic pattern of
   dark longitudinal stripes with black, conical papillae on the dorsal
   side of the body, irregularly arranged white pigment spots, and the lack
   of a nuchal scute. The type locality is Shoal Creek, Austin, Texas, USA.
   Based on the sequence of part of the mitochondrial gene cytochrome c
   oxidase subunit I, H. austinensis n. sp. is a defined taxon that differs
   genetically from other, morphologically similar Helobdella species by 11
   to 17 %. Under laboratory conditions, hungry leeches suck body fluids
   from living freshwater snails, dead (frozen-thawed) Chironomus larvae,
   and crushed (wounded) crustaceans. Aquatic oligochaetes (Tubifex worms)
   and living insect larvae are ignored. This specific prey selection is a
   characteristic feature of H. austinensis, a taxon that differs, based on
   morphological features, from its relatives of the South American
   triserialis species complex. ([copyright] 2013 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH &
   Co. KGaA, Weinheim)
C1 Kutschera, U.; Univ Kassel, Inst Biol, Heinrich Plett Str 40, Kassel,
   D-34132, Germany, Germany.
EM kut@uni-kassel.de
OI Kuo, Dian-Han/0000-0002-6461-2562
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; USA
DE Helobdella austinensis [Texas /  / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Hirudinea
OR Helobdella austinensis (Hirudinea): [Sp nov, Texas, P. 240]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15010052232
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15010052233
DT Article
TI Ryocalanus brasilianus sp nov (Crustacea: Copepoda, Calanoida), a new
   ryocalanoid from the South Atlantic and the segregation of Yrocalanus
   gen. nov.
AU Renz, J. (Jasmin.Renz@senckenberg.de) 
   Markhaseva, E.L.
   Schulz, K.
SO Zoosystematics and Evolution
VL 89
IS 2
PS 247-258
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new hyperbenthic calanoid copepod species, Ryocalanus brasilianus,
   collected from abyssal depth in the Brazilian Basin, is described from
   female and male specimens. The new species is placed in the genus
   Ryocalanus, family Ryocalanidae, on account of the complex
   characteristics of the male antennule and segmentation and setation of
   swimming legs. Ryocalanus brasilianus is distinguished from other
   species of this genus by its larger size, the shape of rostrum and
   urosomite segments, the number of robust spines on the coxa of leg 4 in
   females, and the male P5 and antennule morphology. A new genus,
   Yrocalanus gen. nov. is established to accomodate four species
   previously integrated into Ryocalanus that are distinctive in their
   smaller body size, shape of the rostrum and details of antennule and
   fifth legs of the male. ([copyright] 2013 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co.
   KGaA, Weinheim)
C1 Renz, J.; German Ctr Marine Biodivers Res DZMB Senckenberg, Biozentrum
   Grindel, Martin Luther King Pl 3, Hamburg, D-20146, Germany, Germany.
EM Jasmin.Renz@senckenberg.de

   [Referred to, New genus Yrocalanus, p. 258].

TI A new species of freshwater crab, Travancoriana granulata n. sp
   (Brachyura: Gecarcinucidae) from the southern Western Ghats of India.
AU Pati, S.K. (sameer_pati@yahoo.co.in) 
   Sharma, R.M.
SO Zoosystematics and Evolution
VL 89
IS 2
PS 275-281
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of freshwater crab of the genus Travancoriana Bott, 1969,
   is described from the southern Western Ghats, Eravikulam National Park,
   Idukki district, Kerala, India. The newly described species,
   Travancoriana granulata n. sp., is distinct from the other five known
   species of this genus in some morphological features like parallel
   lateral margins of the frontal, anteriorly placed broad epigastric
   cristae, the squarish sixth male abdominal somite, and gonopod
   structures. A key to the species of Travancoriana is provided.
   ([copyright] 2013 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim)

DT Article
TI A New Species of Choerophryne (Anura: Microhylidae) from Papua New
   Guinea, with remarks on the taxonomic status of Albericus.
AU Kraus, Fred (fkraus@umich.edu) 
SO Zoosystematics and Evolution
VL 89
IS 2
PS 283-291
PD Sep 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB I describe a new species of microhylid frog of the genus Choerophryne
   from an outlying volcanic complex along the northeastern coast of Papua
   New Guinea. The new species is characterized by its marginally elongated
   snout, bright green-and-brown color pattern above, contrasting
   black-and-white color patten below, and call consisting of sparsely
   delivered clicks. Choerophryne and Albericus have been distinguished
   from each other solely on the basis of whether the alary processes of
   the premaxillae are oriented dorsally (Albericus) or anteriorly
   (Choerophryne). The new species is perfectly intermediate between these
   two states, with the alary processes oriented anteriorly at
   approximately a 45-degree angle. The distinction between these two
   genera thus seems to be based on a single character that varies
   continuously between two extremes. The horizontal orientation of the
   alary processes is clearly apomorphic. Hence, Albericus is likely to be
   a paraphyletic basal assemblage and, therefore, a junior synonym of
   Choerophryne. Nonetheless, I defer making this taxonomic change until
   explicit phylogenetic analyses are completed that include multiple
   representatives of both species. ([copyright] 2013 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH
   & Co. KGaA, Weinheim)
C1 Kraus, Fred; Univ Michigan, Dept Ecol & Evolutionary Biol, Ann Arbor,
   MI, 48109, USA, USA.
EM fkraus@umich.edu
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Land zones; Australasian
   region; Australasia
DE Choerophryne bryonopsis [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Microhylidae
OR Albericus - Burton & Zweifel 1995 (Microhylidae): [Status, P. 289]. 
   Choerophryne bryonopsis (Microhylidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P.
   285].

PT J

DT Article
TI Two new species of Plutodes Guenee (1858) from the Philippines and
   Indonesia (Lepidoptera, Geometridae, Ennominae).
AU Stuening, Dieter (D.Stuening@zfmk.de) 
SO Tinea
VL 22
IS 4
PS 253-261
PD Aug 31 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Plutodes, P. noraweltiae sp. n. from Mindanao Island,
   the Philippines, and P. dintelmanni sp. n. from Sulawesi, Indonesia, are
   described. Both are members of the core-group of Plutodes, as
   represented by P. cyclaria Guenee, (1858), the type-species of the
   genus, and related species. P. noraweltiae is closely related to P.
   argentilauta Prout, 1929, described from Burn Island, but also
   distributed in Sulawesi, Borneo and Sumatra. Both species are similar,
   externally and as well in the male genitalia, but distinguished by
   distinct features of the female genitalia. Also by genetic features they
   are well differentiated. P. dintelmanni is a rare, endemic species from
   Sulawesi, externally and in the male and female genitalia resembling P.
   exquisita Butler, 1880, described from N. India. Barcoding results have
   also shown that they are close to each other. A further related species
   is P. joiceyi Prout, 1928, described from Sumatra and not found
   elsewhere.
C1 Stuening, Dieter; Zool Res Museum Alexander Koenig, Adenauerallee 160,
   Bonn, D-53113, Germany, Germany.
EM D.Stuening@zfmk.de
SC Zoology
SN 0493-3168
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Plutodes dintelmanni [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
   Plutodes noraweltiae [Philippines /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Geometroidea, Geometridae
OR Plutodes dintelmanni (Geometridae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 258]. 
   Plutodes noraweltiae (Geometridae): [Sp nov, Philippines, P. 255].

TI New species of lichen-moths from South-East Asia (Lepidoptera,
   Noctuoidea, Lithosiini).
AU Dubatolov, Vladimir V. (vvdubat@mail.ru) 
   Bucsek, Karol

AB 14 new Lithosiinae species Cernyia kosterini sp. nov., Poliosia
   solovyevi sp. nov., Nishada schintlmeisteri sp. nov., Lyclene zinchenkoi
   sp. nov., L. kosterini sp. nov., L. kepica sp. nov., L. kontumica sp.
   nov., Barsine honbaensis sp. nov., B. y-nigrum sp. nov., Chamaita hamata
   sp. nov., Aemene monastyrskii sp. nov., Eugoa nata sp. nov., Neoduma
   alexeikorshunovi sp. nov. and Cyclomilta cambodiaca sp. nov. are
   described from South-East Asia. Holotypes of new species are deposited
   in the Institute of Systematics and Ecology of Animals (Novosibirsk,
   Russia). Eilema arizana (Wileman, 1910) from Taiwan and E. furcatus
   Fang, 2000 from Hainan are transferred into Cernyia Bucsek, 2012: C.
   arizana (Wileman, 1910), comb. nov., C. furcatus (Fang, 2000), comb.
   nov.

DT Article
TI A TAXONOMIC REVIEW OF THE GENUS ASTEROMORPHA LUTKEN (ECHINODERMATA:
   OPHIUROIDEA: EURYALIDAE).
AU Okanishi, Masanori (okahoku@gmail.com) 
   Olbers, Jennifer M.
   Fujita, Toshihiko
SO Raffles Bulletin of Zoology
VL 61
IS 2
PS 461-480
PD Aug 30 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The genus Asteromorpha Lutken (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea: Euryalidae:
   Euryalinae) is revised based on 52 specimens, including six syntypes of
   Asteromorpha steenstrupi, one syntype of Asteromorpha perplexum
   (Koehler), one syntype of Asteromorpha koehleri (Doderlein) and the
   holotype of Astroschema capensis Mortensen. We propose a new combination
   of Asteroschema capense (Euryalidae: Asteroschematinae) with the genus
   Asteromorpha. Consequently Asteromorpha includes four species: A.
   capensis, A. koehleri, A. rousseaui, and A. tenax. These four species
   are all redescribed. A taxonomic key to the species of the genus
   Asteromorpha is also provided.
C1 Okanishi, Masanori; Kyoto Univ, Seto Marine Biol Lab, 459 Shirahama,
   Wakayama, 6492211, Japan, Japan.
EM okahoku@gmail.com
RI Olbers, Jennifer M/C-2438-2017
